quest_title: A truck and a car are moving with equal velocity. On applying the brakes both will stop after certain distance, then
ans1_txt: Truck will cover less distance before rest
ans2_txt: Car will cover less distance before rest
explanation_txt: \(\begin{array} { l } { \text { Stopping distance } = \cfrac { \text { Kinetic energy } } { \text { Retarding force } } = \cfrac { \cfrac { 1 } { 2 } m u ^ { 2 } } { \text { Retarding force } } = \cfrac { \cfrac { 1 } { 2 } m u ^ { 2 } } { F }}\\{\text { If retarding force } ( F ) \text { and velocity } ( v ) \text { are equal then stopping distance }\propto m \text { (mass of vehicle) } } \\ { \text { As } m _ { \text { car } } < m _ { \text { truck } }, \text { therefore car will cover less distance before coming to rest. } } \end{array}\)
question_plain_title: A truck and a car are moving with equal velocity. On applying the brakes both will stop after certain distance, then
ans1_plain_text: Truck will cover less distance before rest
ans2_plain_text: Car will cover less distance before rest

quest_title: Which of the following is radio-active?
explanation_txt:
Protium - common stable isotope of hydrogen (one proton)

Deuterium - heavier isotope of hydrogen (one proton + one neutron)

Tritium - radio-active isotope of hydrogen (one proton + two neutrons); very unstable

quest_title: The first 3 terms in the expansion of \(( 1 + a x ) ^ { n } ( n \neq 0 )\) are 1, 6x and 16x2. Then the value of a and n are respectively
explanation_txt:
\( T _ { 1 } = ^ { n } C _ { 0 } = 1 \dots (i) \\ T _ { 2 } = ^ { n } C _ { 1 } a x = 6 x \dots (ii) \\ T _ { 3 } = ^ { n } C _ { 2 } ( a x ) ^ { 2 } = 16 x ^ { 2 } \dots (iii) \)

From (ii) \( \cfrac { n ! } { ( n - 1 ) ! } a = 6 \Rightarrow n a = 6 \dots (iv) \)

From (iii) \( \cfrac { n ( n - 1 ) } { 2 } a ^ { 2 } = 16 \dots (v) \)

Simplifying (v), \( (an)^2 - (na)a = 32 \)

Put \( na = 6\), \( 36 - 6a = 32 \Rightarrow a = 2/3 \)

From (iv), \( n = 9 \)

quest_title: A solution of sulphur dioxide in water reacts with \(H_{2} S\) precipitating sulphur. Here sulphur dioxide acts as
explanation_txt:
When sulphur dioxide is react with \(H_{2} S\) here \(SO_{2} \) act as an oxidising agent and \(H_{2} S\) act as reducing agent.

\(H_2\overset{-2}S+\overset{+4}SO_2 \to \overset{0}S + H_2O\)

Here \(SO_2\) is reduced to \(S\) and \( H_2S\) is oxidised to \(S\).

quest_title: A parallel plate condenser of capacity \(\text{C}\) is connected to a battery and is charged to a potential \(\text{V}\). Another condenser of capacity 2\(\text{C}\) is connected to another battery and is charged to a potential 2\(\text{V}\). The charging batteries are removed and now the condensers are connected in parallel in such a way that the positive plate of one is connected to negative plate of other. The final energy of system is
explanation_txt:
The common potential is given by

\(\begin{array}{l}{V=\cfrac{C_{2} V_{2}-C_{1} V_{1}}{C_{1}+C_{2}}} \\ {V=\cfrac{2 C \times 2 V-C V}{2 +C}=V}\end{array}\)

The energy stored in combination is given by:

\(U=\cfrac{1}{2} C^{\prime} V^{2}=\cfrac{1}{2} 3 C V^{2}\)

\(\therefore \quad U=\cfrac{3}{2} C V^{2}\)

quest_title: A magnet of magnetic moment M is situated with its axis along the direction of a magnetic field of strength B. The work done in rotating it by an angle of 180o will be
explanation_txt:
Work done (W) \(=\int \tau d\theta=\int_{\theta_{1}}^{\theta_{2}} MBsin\theta d\theta= M B \left( \cos \theta _ { 1 } - \cos \theta _ { 2 } \right)\)

For \(\theta _ { 1 } = 0 ^ { \circ }\) and \(\theta _ { 2 } = 180 ^ { \circ },\)

\(W = M B ( \cos 0 - \cos 180 ) = 2 M B \)

quest_title: Two bar magnets of the same mass, same length and breadth but having magnetic moments \({M}\) and \({2M}\) are joined together pole to pole and suspended by a string. The time period of assembly in a magnetic field of strength \({H}\) is 3 second. If now the polarity of one of the magnets is reversed and the combination is again made to oscillate in the same field, the time of oscillation is
explanation_txt:
In first position, \(M^{\prime}=2 M+M=3 M\)
In second position, \(M^{\prime}=2 M-M=M\)
\(\therefore 3=2 \pi \sqrt{\cfrac{I}{3 M \times B_{H}}}\) \(\ldots \ldots\) (i)
and \(T=2 \pi \sqrt{\cfrac{I}{M B_{H}}}\). \(\ldots \ldots .\) (ii)
Dividing (ii) by (i) we get, \(T=3 \sqrt{3}\) sec.
question_plain_title: Two bar magnets of the same mass, same length and breadth but having magnetic moments and are joined together pole to pole and suspended by a string. The time period of assembly in a magnetic field of strength is 3 second. explanation_plain_text:
In first position,
In second position,
(i)
and . (ii)
Dividing (ii) by (i) we get, sec.

quest_title:
The standard reduction potentials at 298 K for the following half – reactions are given against each 
 \(\text{\(Zn\)\(^{2+}\)}\) + \(\text{2e\(^{–}\)}\) \(\rightarrow\) Zn E° = – 0.760 \(v\) 
 \(\text{Cr\(^{3+}\)}\) + \(\text{3e\(^{–}\)}\) \(\rightarrow\) CrE° –0.74 \(v\) 
 \(\text{2H\(^{+}\)}\) + \(\text{2e\(^{–}\)}\) \(\text{\(\rightarrow\)H\(_{2}\),E°}\) = OV 
 \(\text{Fe\(^{3+}\)}\) + \(\text{e\(^{–}\)}\) \(\rightarrow\) \(\text{Fe\(^{2+}\)E°}\) = \(\text{0.770\( v\)}\) 
 Which is the strongest reducing agent?
explanation_txt: -0.76 is the smallest of all the values. It imples that Zn++ has the least tendency to get reduced, thus the most tendency to get oxidized, thereby being the strongest reducing agent.

quest_title: \(\displaystyle \int e^{x}\left(\log x+\cfrac{1}{x}\right) d x=\)
Two balls of the same mass are shot upwards one after another at an interval of 2 seconds along the same vertical line with the same initial velocity of 40 m/s. They will collide at a height
explanation_txt:
For 1st,

\(\mathrm{h}=\mathrm{ut}-\cfrac{1}{2} \mathrm{g} \mathrm{t}^{2}=40 \mathrm{t}-\cfrac{1}{2} \mathrm{gt}^{2}\)

For 2nd,

\(\begin{aligned} h &=u(t-2)-\cfrac{1}{2} g(t-2)^{2} \\ &=40(t-2)-\cfrac{1}{2} g(t-2)^{2} \end{aligned}\)

Now,

\(\text { or, } 40 \mathrm{t}-\cfrac{1}{2} \mathrm{gt}^{2}=40(\mathrm{t}-2)-\cfrac{1}{2} \mathrm{g}\left(\mathrm{t}^{2}-4 \mathrm{t}+4\right) \)
\(\text { or, } 40 \mathrm{t}-\cfrac{1}{2} \mathrm{gt}^{2}=40 \mathrm{t}-80-\cfrac{1}{2} \mathrm{gt}^{2}+2 \mathrm{gt}-2 \mathrm{g} \)
\(\text { or, } 80+2 \times 10=2 \times 10 \mathrm{t} \)
\(\text { or, } \mathrm{t}=\cfrac{100}{20}=5 \)

\(\begin{aligned} \therefore \mathrm{h} &=40 \times 5-\cfrac{1}{2} \times 10 \times 5^{2} \\ &=200-125=75 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}\)

quest_title:
A mass 1 kg is suspended by a thread. It is

(i) lifted up with an acceleration 4.9 m/s2

(ii) lowered with an acceleration 4.9 m/s2.

The ratio of the tensions is
explanation_txt:
\( T _ { 1 } = m ( g + a ) = 1 \times \left( g + \cfrac { g } { 2 } \right) = \cfrac { 3 g } { 2 } \)

\( T _ { 2 } = m ( g - a ) = 1 \times \left( g - \cfrac { g } { 2 } \right) = \cfrac { g } { 2 }\)

\(\therefore \cfrac { T _ { 1 } } { T _ { 2 } } = \cfrac { 3 } { 1 } \)

quest_title: Three faradays of electricity are passed through molten Al2O3, aqueous solution of CuSO4 and molten NaCl taken in different electrolytic cells. The amount of Al, Cu and Na deposited at the cathodes will be in the ratio of
explanation_txt:
At cathode: \(Al^{3+} + 3e^{-} \longrightarrow Al\)

\(E_{Al} = \cfrac{\text{Atomic mass}}{3}\)

At cathode: \(Cu^{2+} + 2e^{-} \longrightarrow Cu\)

\(E_{Cu} = \cfrac{\text{Atomic mass}}{2}\)

At cathode: \(Na^{+} + e^{-} \longrightarrow Na\)

\(E_{Na} = \cfrac{\text{Atomic mass}}{1}\)

For the passage of 3 faraday;

mole atoms of Al deposited = 1

mole atoms of Cu deposited = \(\cfrac{1 \times 3}{2} = 1.5\)

mole atoms of Na deposited = 1 x 3 = 3.

quest_title: The weight of iodine librated when 100ml of 2M \(\text{CuSO\({}_{4}\)}\) solution is treated with excess of KI \(\text{sol\({}^{n}\)}\) is
explanation_txt:
100 ml of 2M CuSO\(_4\) = 100 ml of 4N CuSO\(_4\) = 0.1 * 4 = 0.4 gram equivalents

Weight of iodine liberated = No. of gram equivalents \(\times\) Equivalent weight of Iodine = 0.4 * 127 = 50.8 gm

quest_title: An iceberg floats in sea water of density of 1g/cc. The % of volume outside water is if density of iceberg is 0.9 g/cc
explanation_txt: \(\begin{array}{l}{\text { wt }=\text { upthrust }} \\ {\text { or, } \operatorname{vpg}=\mathrm{v}^{\prime} \sigma_{\mathrm{w}} \mathrm{g}} \\ {\therefore \cfrac{\mathrm{v}^{\prime}}{\mathrm{v}}=\cfrac{\rho}{\sigma}=\cfrac{0.9}{1}=\cfrac{9}{10}} \\ {\text { Faction outside }=1-\cfrac{9}{10}=\cfrac{1}{10}} \\ {\% \text { outside }=\cfrac{1}{10} \times 100 \%=10 \%}\end{array}\)

quest_title: 500ml of a 0.1N solution of \(\text{AgNO\({}_{3}\)}\) are added to 500ml of 0.1N solution of KCl. The concentration of nitrate ion in the resulting mixture is
explanation_txt:
Concentration of nitrate ion in 500 ml of 0.1 N \(AgNO_3\) = 0.1 N

Amount of nitrate ion in [500 ml of 0.1 N \(AgNO_3\) + 500 ml of KCl] = 500 ml of 0.1 N = 1000 ml of 0.05 N

\(\therefore\) Concentration of nitrate ion = 0.05 N

Concentration of nitrate ion = 0.05 N

quest_title: A man who can swim is still water with a speed of 2 m/s wants to cross a river 200 m breadth flowing with a speed of 1 m/s. The time of crossing the river by shortest route is
explanation_txt: \(\begin{array}{l}{\sin \alpha=\cfrac{\mathrm{v}_{\mathrm{r}}}{\mathrm{v}_{p}}=\cfrac{1}{2}=\sin 30^{\circ}} \\ {\therefore \alpha=30^{\circ}} \\ {\quad \text { Time }(\mathrm{t})=\cfrac{\mathrm{AB}}{\mathrm{v}_{\mathrm{p}} \cos \alpha}=\cfrac{200}{2 \cos 30}=115.5 \mathrm{sec}}\end{array}\)

quest_title: A hot air balloon of 600m\({}^{3}\) just hover in surrounding of density 1.25kg/m\({}^{3}\). The density of air inside is 0.8kg/m\({}^{3}\) then mass of envelope is
explanation_txt: \(\begin{array}{l}{\mathrm{Wt}=\text { upthrust }} \\ {\text { or, } \mathrm{mg}=\mathrm{V} \sigma_{0} \mathrm{g}} \\ {\text { or, } \mathrm{m}=600 \times 1.25=750 \mathrm{kg}} \\ {\therefore \mathrm{m}_{\mathrm{e}}=\mathrm{m}-\mathrm{m}_{\mathrm{a}}} \\ {\quad=750-\mathrm{V} \sigma_{\mathrm{a}}} \\ {\quad=750-600 \times 0.8} \\ {\quad=750-480} \\ {\quad=270 \mathrm{kg}}\end{array}\)

quest_title: The locus of the centre of a circle, which touches externally the given two circles, is :
explanation_txt:
Consider two circles with centers at \( C_1 (1,0), C_2 (-1,0) \) and radii of \(R_1 =1,R_2=2\).

If \( C(x,y) \) is the center of the circle which touches both these circles and \(r\) is its radius, then \( CC_1 -CC_2 = R_1 - R_2\)

So, \( \sqrt{ {(x-1)}^2 + y^2} = \sqrt{ {(x+1)}^2 + y^2} - 1 \\ (x-1)^2 + y^2 = (x+1)^2 + y^2 + 1 - 2\sqrt{(x+1)^2+y^2} \\ (x-1)^2 - (x+1)^2 - 1 = -2 \sqrt{(x+1)^2+y^2} \\ (x-1+x+1)(x-1-x-1) -1 = -2 \sqrt{(x+1)^2+y^2} \\ (4x + 1) = 2 \sqrt{(x+1)^2+y^2} \)

Squaring and simplifying;

\( 12x^2 - y^2 = 3 \)

which is a hyperbola.

explanation_plain_text:
Consider two circles with centers at and radii of .

If is the center of the circle which touches both these circles and is its radius, then

which is a hyperbola.

One car moving on a straight road covers one third of the distance with 20 km/hr and the rest with 60 km/hr. The average speed is
explanation_txt: \(\begin{array} { l } { \text { Average speed } = \cfrac { \text { Total distance } } { \text { Total time } } = \cfrac { x } { t _ { 1 } + t _ { 2 } } } \\ { = \cfrac { x } { \cfrac { x / 3 } { v _ { 1 } } + \cfrac { 2 x / 3 } { v _ { 2 } } } = \cfrac { 1 } { \cfrac { 1 } { 3 \times 20 } + \cfrac { 2 } { 3 \times 60 } } = 36 \mathrm { km } / \mathrm { hr } } \end{array}\)

quest_title: Two infinite plane parallel sheets separated by a distance \(d\) have equal and opposite uniform charge densities \(\sigma\). Electric field at a point between the sheets is
ans4_txt: Depends upon the location of the point
explanation_txt:
Electric field at a point (P) due to left infinite plate having uniform charge distribution \((\sigma)=\cfrac{\sigma}{2\varepsilon_{0}} \)

Electric field at P due to right infinite plate having uniform charge distribution \((-\sigma)=\cfrac{\sigma}{2\varepsilon_{0}} \)

Total electric field at point in between the plates = \(\cfrac{\sigma}{2\varepsilon_{0}}+\cfrac{\sigma}{2\varepsilon_{0}}=\cfrac{\sigma}{\varepsilon_{0}}\)
question_plain_title: Two infinite plane parallel sheets separated by a distance have equal and opposite uniform charge densities . Electric field at a point between the sheets is
explanation_plain_text:
Electric field at a point (P) due to left infinite plate having uniform charge distribution

Electric field at P due to right infinite plate having uniform charge distribution

Total electric field at point in between the plates =
ans4_plain_text: Depends upon the location of the point

quest_title: The interior angles of a polygon are in A.P. If the smallest angle be \(120^{o} \) and the common difference be 5\({}^{o}\), then the number of sides is
explanation_txt:
Let the number of sides of the polygon be \(n\).

Then the sum of interior angles of the polygon \(=(2n-4)\cfrac{\pi }{2} =(n-2)\pi \)

Since the angles are in A.P. and \(a=120^{o} ,\; d=5\), therefore \(\cfrac{n}{2} [2\times 120+(n-1)5]=(n-2)180\)

\(\Rightarrow n^{2} -25n+144=0 \)

\( \Rightarrow(n-9)(n-16)=0\)

\( \Rightarrow n=9,\; 16\)

But \(n=16\) gives \(T_{16} =a+15d=120^{o} +15.5^{o} =195^{o} \), which is impossible as interior angle cannot be greater than \(180^{o} \). Hence \(n=9\).

quest_title: If \(\tan \theta +\tan 2\theta +\sqrt{3} \tan \theta \tan 2\theta =\sqrt{3} ,\)then
explanation_txt:
Given relation is \(\tan \theta +\tan 2\theta +\sqrt{3} \tan \theta \tan 2\theta =\sqrt{3} \)

\(\Rightarrow \, \tan \theta +\tan 2\theta =\sqrt{3} (1-\tan \theta \tan 2\theta )\)

\(\Rightarrow \cfrac{\tan \theta +\tan 2\theta }{1-\tan \theta \tan 2\theta } = \sqrt{3} \)

\( \Rightarrow \tan 3\theta =\tan (\pi /3)\)

\(\Rightarrow 3\theta =n\pi +\cfrac{\pi }{3} \)

\(\Rightarrow \theta =(3n+1)\cfrac{\pi }{9} .\)

explanation_plain_text: Given relation is
